channel.title: NYT > Movies
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: ‘Wake Up Dead Man: A Knives Out Mystery’ Review: Forgive Them, Father
item.description: Josh O’Connor leads a star-studded cast in the latest Benoit Blanc mystery — this one, about religious cults of personality.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson
item.category: Wake Up Dead Man: A Knives Out Mystery (Movie)

item.title: ‘The Secret Agent’ Review: Wagner Moura Is on the Run
item.description: Wagner Moura takes cover in this knockout from the filmmaker Kleber Mendonça Filho that is largely set in 1977 during Brazil’s miliary dictatorship.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

item.title: ‘Hamnet’ Review: The Rest Is Silence
item.description: Jessie Buckley and Paul Mescal star in a heartbreaking adaptation of the best-selling novel.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson

item.title: ‘Zootopia 2’ Review: Natural Habitats, Expanded
item.description: A sequel to the 2016 hit, this movie about an animal metropolis takes on an even messier social allegory than the first one, while building out a wider (if bloated) universe.
item.dc:creator: Brandon Yu

item.title: ‘Eternity’ Review: Dead Reckoning
item.description: Elizabeth Olsen plays a dead woman who must choose her forever partner in this silly afterlife rom-com.
item.dc:creator: Jeannette Catsoulis

item.title: ‘Teenage Wasteland’ Review: Young in Age, Mature in Reporting
item.description: This documentary looks back at a group of teenagers who, in the early 1990s, created a high school video project that ended up breaking real news.
item.dc:creator: Ben Kenigsberg

item.title: How 2 New Songs Made Their Way Into ‘Wicked: For Good’
item.description: Each witch gets a new number as part of an effort to flesh out the arc of the stage show’s second act.
item.dc:creator: Esther Zuckerman

item.title: Five Free Movies to Stream Now
item.description: For the Thanksgiving holiday, this month’s picks, including “Force Majeure” and “The Humans,” look at family togetherness in all its mundane glory.
item.dc:creator: Brandon Yu

item.title: Rose Byrne and Sheila Heti on Parenting, A.I. and the Nature of Personality
item.description: The “If I Had Legs I’d Kick You” actor and the author of “Alphabetical Diaries” met for a wide-ranging conversation.
item.dc:creator: Kate Guadagnino
item.category: If I Had Legs I'd Kick You (Movie)

item.title: Udo Kier, Familiar Movie Villain and Fixture of the Offbeat, Dies at 81
item.description: A German-born actor, he appeared in more than 280 films, from Hollywood action fare to a Warhol horror tale. Madonna liked him for her videos.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams
item.media:description: Udo Kier in a scene from Gus Van Sant’s “My Own Private Idaho” (1991). He gravitated to transgressive fare.

item.title: With Tom Felton, ‘Harry Potter’ Breaks Its Own Broadway Record
item.description: The actor is now playing an adult version of the sinister child he portrayed in the film series.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.category: Harry Potter and the Cursed Child (Play)
item.media:description: Tom Felton, left, as Draco Malfoy and John Skelley as Harry Potter in “Harry Potter and the Cursed Child” at the Lyric Theater.

item.title: ‘Queen of Versailles’ to Close as New Broadway Musicals Struggle
item.description: The show, starring Kristin Chenoweth, will remain open through the holidays. The announcement comes just two weeks after the musical opened.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.media:description: Kristin Chenoweth in “The Queen of Versailles” at the St. James Theater.

item.title: Jimmy Cliff Brought Reggae to the Masses with ‘The Harder They Come’
item.description: The 1972 film “The Harder They Come” and its accompanying soundtrack brought the genre out of Jamaica and helped pave the way for future stars.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Abrams
item.media:description: The soundtrack to “The Harder They Come,” featuring several Jimmy Cliff songs, is one of reggae’s most important recordings.

item.title: Lee Tamahori, Director of Film Voted New Zealand’s Best, Dies at 75
item.description: He reimagined “Once Were Warriors,” a novel about a Maori family, as a film that became a worldwide phenomenon. He went on to direct Hollywood movies.
item.dc:creator: Alex Traub
item.media:description: A scene from the 1994 film “Once Were Warriors,” directed by Lee Tamahori. It became the highest-grossing film in New Zealand’s history.

item.title: Stream These 5 Movies and TV Shows Before They Leave Netflix in December
item.description: Departures for U.S. subscribers next month include several classic comedies of the big and small screen — and one particularly prescient one.
item.dc:creator: Jason Bailey
item.media:description: Terry Crews (second from left) and Luke Wilson (second from right) in “Idiocracy.”

item.title: ‘Wicked: For Good’ Tells a Story Through Color
item.description: Alice Brooks, the cinematographer of “Wicked: For Good,” explains the meaning and intention behind the color choices in the film.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr, Edward Vega, Gabriel Blanco and Laura Salaberry

item.title: Da’Vine Joy Randolph Loves Ocean Swims, Minus the Snorkeling
item.description: “I have a phobia of what lies beneath,” the Oscar winner said. “I don’t want to know what’s down there! Don’t touch me and I won’t touch you.”
item.dc:creator: Leigh-Ann Jackson

item.title: Timothée Chalamet Draws Huge Crowd for ‘Marty Supreme’ Merch Pop-Up
item.description: Mr. Chalamet’s star power was in full force in Manhattan as fans clamored to get merch for “Marty Supreme,” a movie none of them will see until Christmas.
item.dc:creator: Jacob Gallagher and Graham Dickie
item.media:credit: Graham Dickie for The New York Times

item.title: Five Science Fiction Movies to Stream Now
item.description: In this month’s picks, there is cloud busting in Peru, a shadowy astronaut drama, doomsday preppers in New Zealand and more.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli

item.title: Watch a ‘Wonderful’ Moment From ‘Wicked: For Good’
item.description: The director Jon M. Chu narrates a sequence from his film featuring Ariana Grande, Cynthia Erivo and Jeff Goldblum performing the song “Wonderful.”
item.dc:creator: Mekado Murphy

item.title: ‘Wicked: For Good’ — Ariana Grande and Cynthia Erivo’s Never-Ending Press Tour
item.description: The pink-and-green-themed promotions were everywhere, with all the advantages and limitations that kind of marketing push entails.
item.dc:creator: Esther Zuckerman
item.media:description: From left, Ariana Grande, and Cynthia Erivo greeted fans at Universal Studios Singapore last week.

item.title: 6 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
item.description: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: ‘Zodiac Killer Project’: Hooked on True Crime
item.description: Charlie Shackleton explains how he would have made a film had he won the rights to a book on a murderer. The result is a fascinating look at a whole genre.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson

item.title: ‘Toy Story’ at 30: Animation Has Never Been the Same
item.description: The Pixar Era kicked off 30 years ago with the first installment of the popular franchise. It’s given us countless hits, but something has also been lost.
item.dc:creator: Maya Phillips

item.title: ‘Wicked: For Good’ | Anatomy of a Scene
item.description: The director Jon M. Chu narrates a sequence from his film featuring Cynthia Erivo, Ariana Grande and Jeff Goldblum.
item.dc:creator: Mekado Murphy

item.title: ‘The Age of Disclosure,’ Documentary About U.F.O.s, Gets a Congressional Audience
item.description: “The Age of Disclosure,” a documentary featuring government and military officials, was screened for a bipartisan group of members of the House of Representatives.
item.dc:creator: Ralph Blumenthal and Leslie Kean
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Justin T. Gellerson for The New York Times
item.media:description: The director Dan Farah at a showing of his film, “The Age of Disclosure,” in Washington.

item.title: ‘The Family Plan 2’ Review: A Relaxing Vacation? Maybe Not.
item.description: Mark Wahlberg and Michelle Monaghan return in a better executed, equally goofball sequel about a family’s tangles with organized crime.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Kennedy

item.title: Netflix Has a New House in the Suburbs: Come In and Chill
item.description: After a string of successful events and activities, the streamer has opened its first permanent home for branded fun, at a mall near Philadelphia.
item.dc:creator: Alexis Soloski and Michelle Gustafson
item.category: Netflix House Philadelphia (King of Prussia, Pa)
item.media:credit: Michelle Gustafson for The New York Times

item.title: ‘Wicked: For Good’ Review: Two Besties Till the End
item.description: Cynthia Erivo and Ariana Grande return to Oz for the second part of Jon M. Chu’s maximalist adaptation of the Broadway musical.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

item.title: ‘Train Dreams’ Review: Life, Understood in Reverse
item.description: Joel Edgerton stars in a gorgeous film based on Denis Johnson’s celebrated novella about a laborer in the Pacific Northwest.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson

item.title: ‘Stop the Insanity: Finding Susan Powter’ Review: When Fame Recedes
item.description: A documentary tracks the highs and lows of the 1990s fitness guru, now a food delivery driver in Las Vegas.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Kenny
item.category: Stop the Insanity: Finding Susan Powter (Movie)

item.title: ‘Sisu: Road to Revenge’ Review: Slapstick Rambo
item.description: In this sequel to the 2023 exploitation film, blood-splattered inanity becomes a delirium of popcorn fun.
item.dc:creator: Brandon Yu

item.title: ‘Rental Family’ Review: Brendan Fraser, Lost in Impersonation
item.description: Brendan Fraser is quietly endearing in this fish-out-of-water tale of an American actor in Tokyo who accepts some highly unusual assignments.
item.dc:creator: Jeannette Catsoulis

item.title: ‘Cutting Through Rocks’ Review: The Only Way Out
item.description: A documentary about Sara Shahverdi, the first woman elected to the council of her village in Iran, is propelled by her no-nonsense resourcefulness.
item.dc:creator: Sheri Linden

item.title: ‘The Age of Disclosure’ Review: Release the Extraterrestrial Files
item.description: A documentary argues that the U.S. government needs to divulge what it knows about the phenomena formerly called U.F.O.s.
item.dc:creator: Ben Kenigsberg

item.title: ‘Cactus Pears’ Review: Finding Intimacy Amid Grief
item.description: This understated Indian drama follows closeted gay man gingerly initiating a romance with an old friend.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Winkelman
